articles.headline: One Number to Ring Them All
articles.snippet: Google Voice has breathed new life into GrandCentral, a service that lets all your phones respond to one number.
articles.abstract: Google Voice has breathed new life into GrandCentral, a service that lets all your phones respond to one number.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Google search revolutionized the Web, and Gmail revolutionized free e-mail, then one thing’s for sure: Google Voice, unveiled Thursday, will revolutionize telephones.

articles.headline: China’s Big Recycling Market Is Sagging
articles.snippet: China’s export downturn means a lesser need for recycled waste from the U.S., and trash is piling up.
articles.abstract: China’s export downturn means a lesser need for recycled waste from the U.S., and trash is piling up.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Each morning Tian Wengui emerges from the home he makes under a bridge here, two large sacks slung over his shoulder. Through the day, and well into the night, he scours garbage cans for soda bottles, soy sauce containers and cooking oil jugs. Selling the refuse to one of Beijing’s ubiquitous recycling depots, Mr. Tian can earn $3 on a good day.

articles.headline: Financial Fraud Is Focus of Attack by Prosecutors
articles.snippet: State attorneys general are preparing for a surge of prosecutions of financial fraud, and there are hints the Obama administration’s budget will add to the effort.
articles.abstract: State attorneys general are preparing for a surge of prosecutions of financial fraud, and there are hints the Obama administration’s budget will add to the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: Spurred by rising public anger, federal and state investigators are preparing for a surge of prosecutions of financial fraud.

articles.headline: Google Co-Founder Backs Vast Parkinson’s Study
articles.snippet: Sergey Brin says he plans to contribute money and his DNA to a large genetic study of Parkinson’s disease.
articles.abstract: Sergey Brin says he plans to contribute money and his DNA to a large genetic study of Parkinson’s disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sergey Brin, the billionaire co-founder of Google, says he plans to contribute money and his DNA to a large study intended to reveal the genetic underpinnings of Parkinson’s disease.

articles.headline: Europe Faulted on Too-Tepid Stimulus
articles.snippet: As the evidence of economic pain mounts in Europe, a growing number of analysts say the Continent’s leaders are reacting too slowly.
articles.abstract: As the evidence of economic pain mounts in Europe, a growing number of analysts say the Continent’s leaders are reacting too slowly.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  As the evidence of economic pain mounts in Europe, a growing number of analysts say the Continent’s leaders are reacting too slowly.

articles.headline: At Stake for Madoff in Hearing: His Freedom
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff’s bail status is the biggest question mark hanging over the court hearing where he is expected to plead guilty to operating a vast Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff’s bail status is the biggest question mark hanging over the court hearing where he is expected to plead guilty to operating a vast Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Bernard L. Madoff arrives in federal court on Thursday to plead guilty to operating a vast 20-year Ponzi scheme, there is a strong chance that he will not return home.

articles.headline: A Dirty Pun Tweaks China’s Online Censors
articles.snippet: A craze over a mythical beast conceived as an impish protest raises questions about China’s Internet censorship.
articles.abstract: A craze over a mythical beast conceived as an impish protest raises questions about China’s Internet censorship.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Since its first unheralded appearance in January on a Chinese Web page, the grass-mud horse has become nothing less than a phenomenon.

articles.headline: As Cities Go From Two Papers to One, Talk of Zero
articles.snippet: No one knows which will be the first big city without a large newspaper, but there are candidates across the U.S.
articles.abstract: No one knows which will be the first big city without a large newspaper, but there are candidates across the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: The history of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer stretches back more than two decades before Washington became a state, but after 146 years of publishing, the paper is expected to print its last issue next week, perhaps surviving only in a much smaller online version.

articles.headline: Investors See a Glimmer and Shares Soar Worldwide
articles.snippet: Investors found financial news not as bad as feared, galvanizing worldwide stock exchanges, but few experts are willing to call an end to the bear market.
articles.abstract: Investors found financial news not as bad as feared, galvanizing worldwide stock exchanges, but few experts are willing to call an end to the bear market.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few clues that the economy’s downward spiral might be slowing galvanized Wall Street on Thursday and sent the stock market soaring for the second time this week.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Madoff Goes to Jail After Guilty Pleas
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff was sent to jail to await sentencing after expressing remorse for his Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff was sent to jail to await sentencing after expressing remorse for his Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Bernard L. Madoff entered a federal courtroom in Manhattan on Thursday to admit that he had run a vast Ponzi scheme that robbed thousands of investors of their life savings, he was as elegantly dressed as ever. But, preparing for jail, he wore no wedding ring  only the shadowy imprint remained of one he has worn for nearly 50 years.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Jack Healy
